Expectation1: Provide guidance to clients regarding machine usage
Situation1: Inexperienced staff are about to run a hazardous batch without understanding safety protocols.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: I stood in the humming factory, sweat prickling my neck as I watched the new staff fumble with the control panel. They were about to start a batch, but I could see from their nervous glances and uncertain hands that they hadn’t grasped the safety protocols. My job was clear: I had to step in, guide them, and make sure no one got hurt. But my phone buzzed with a reminder—I was due at the polling station across town. I rushed over, only to find a long line snaking out the door. An official called out, “Last names A–M, please move to the new line!” My last name started with B, but the new line was barely moving. The original line, where I’d been waiting, was much faster. I was torn. As a voter, I was expected to follow the official’s instructions, but as a machine repairer, I knew I needed to get back to the factory soon to prevent a possible accident. My mind raced, caught between the duty to keep people safe at work and the responsibility to respect the voting process.
